text: A group of friends and I recently went to go visit Nanay.. the food was good esp. the Bistek and Sinigang but it was all good really. You can't beat the price. We went at an off time about 5pm on Saturday. We were the only ones in the restaurant. When we left business was picking up quite well. The only downfall was Nanay kinda came back with us in a way and when she tried to leave us it was through our Glori-holes. I'd go back again but those who have a refined palate may pass.

I really want to impress on readers how this restaurant has gone downhill within the last couple of years.  Nanay Gloria's on Maryland Parkway used to be a good deal for your dollar, but things have changed, and I feel, it's to save money as much as possible.  Firstly, if you have children between the ages of 1-3 years old, they will be charged.  It doesn't sound like a lot--$1.99, but more respectable buffet eateries don't usually subscribe to such practices.  Still, they didn't use to do this.  Secondly, they've gotten rid of trays.  Yes, trays.  This is a cafeteria style buffet line, and you are expected to fill your plate and carry it to your table by hand.  That means multiple trips back to get water and your silverware.  God forbid that you happen to be carrying soup...and with a kid in tow.  Talk about an accident waiting to happen.  I honestly feel they got rid of the trays to discourage customers from filling their plates.  I actually asked them why they got rid of them, and no one could give me a decent answer.  But, trays are just practical at any eatery, and I strongly condemn this restaurant for  getting rid of them.  I've always liked their kare-kare (ox-tail and tripe in a peanuty broth) which is always complemented by a sauteed shrimp paste (known as ginisang bagoong).  I remember how I used to love their sauteed shrimp paste.  Now, it tastes as if the shrimp paste is coming straight from the jar without being sauteed.  The pancit was left wanting, as it was more noodle than anything.  There were big chunks of the "rootier" parts of the cabbage--not the leafy part, and it left the dish tasting too bitter.   Their curried chicken at the time I dined there, had veggies that were undercooked, and I happened to scoop up the chicken's neckbone, which, in my opinion, wasn't going to do a ravenous diner any favors.  Do they expect that I'll be sucking on a length of neckbone just to lap up the last bits of curry?  If they want to add it for flavoring, they should remove it prior to serving.  The dessert items are very limited.  They always have a hot dessert on the food line, but the selection of fruits and other sweets were very limited.  Trying to sit down to a clean table was almost impossible.  Even the cleanest table that we were at felt sticky to the touch.  They need to not only remove dishes, but they need to really wipe down their tables (and chairs) better.  In all, I think Nanay Gloria's likes to rely on the reputation it had in the past.  As a local here, I can honestly say that customers are better off eating elsewhere.  I am no longer impressed.

Love Filipino buffets! Las Vegas has a huge Filipino population. And that means the Filipino restaurants here are authentic. Nanay Gloria's buffet is the closest U will get to experience authentic Filipino cuisines for just $9.99. Suprise not too many people know or Yelp about this fantastic location. Oh well! Your lost, my gain.

This restaurant is over rated. It actually sucks. Nothing special about it. It doesn't taste like home cooked or your Mom's cooking like the name suggests. No, I wouldn't take someone else here and won't recommend it. The photos make it look good but in person, not really a nice sit down restaurant. It's small and dark and I feel like not very clean too. Also no ambience at all. I wonder if those who reviewed it positively are part of their friends and families.

Our first time here and we were very impressed. Wonderful selection of filipino dishes. All tasted great. The staff were all so nice. The place is clean. We don't  have many filipino buffets like this in the Bay Area, so this was a treat. And the price was unbelievable! We will def be coming back! I've never been to the other location, so next trip to LV, we will compare but I'm sure it's just as great. Thank you Nanay Gloria!!!

We pre-order a whole lechon for my mom's 85th birthday bash and deposited $100 cash  two weeks in advanced. When its time for pick up on jan 4, 2014 sat.  The employee from nanay gloria  has no clue whats going on and did not even attempted to remedy the situation. It's good thing we kept the reciept and got back our money. The bad part is my mom is expecting a huge crowd approximately  50 people , some of them from out of town.  We have to scramble  our resources to accomodate our guest. Nanay gloria  employee  did nothing to help us out, no explanation how they lost our lechon . Very unprofessional and uncompassionate !!! Kabalen pa naman! :(

We came to this spot for the first time because we've heard some good things about this place but I guess we came on a bad day? $8.99 per person for buffet excluding drinks; that's fine. Fountain soda machine wasn't working; no refills, you're forced to buy another drink (Wala bang discount?!). Rice was dried out and crunchy, had 1 slice of lime (not lemon) for the pancit, dinaguan tasted like it was cooked with old oil -oh what the hell?!  Just messed up the mood for Filipino food! Disappointed. :p Hella not comin back to this place. I'll take my ten bucks down the street to the other Filipino restaurant accross the street from the Boulevard Mall and they have more variety. No wonder why this place was empty.

I am so embarrassed!  I saw the awesome review for the Nanay Gloria's on Spring Mountain (over here:    http://www.yelp.com/biz/Ta4GRuHyZvU5H_l5IAG1PQ) and couldn't wait to try it.  I pass by a "Nanay Gloria's" on Maryland Pkwy pretty regularly and thought the two places were related, so I decided to try it today.  

It looks like there is supposed to be a little market on the left side, but it was closed, so I couldn't check it out.

Based on the reviews for the other place, I don't think there is any possible way these two Nanay Gloria's are related.  This Nanay Gloria's was the standard steam-table counter place, where you can order a 2 or 3 item plate with rice.  I had:

- lechon paksiw: chunks of roasted pork with crispy skin - pretty fatty, but not bad
- fried bangus: milkfish -  very dry 
- kare kare: peanut butter stew - was not made out of the traditional oxtails, but with huge chunks of mystery fat and bone (possibly beef neckbones?).  Had very little flavor.
- beefsteak: Philipino style with onions - swimming in grease and pretty flavorless
- garlic fried rice - tasty in a really greasy sorta way
- Coke in a can - the best part of my meal :)

I have been feeling so sluggish and nasty all day because of all the grease and fat I consumed at lunch today.  I have been to quite a few Philipino places in Las Vegas and I can honestly say this has been the worst so far.  With Goldilocks just across one street, and Sarili Atin and DJ's across the other street, there are plenty of more flavorful and less greasy choices for Philipino fare.  I can honestly say I will never go back to this Nanay Gloria's LOL.  But I still want to try the other one!
All you can eat filipino food buffet. Delicious, affordable, friendly environment, TFC shows on TV screen =)

Love the food. Even though location wasn't so pleasant to see, the food was great. If you're going to get the buffet. Eat food first then water. If you load up on rice you'll get full right away. The fruits weren't fresh but the dessert was yummy. I miss Filipino food. Can't have any at home due to strict diets folks have. I love the chocolate meat. Would have loved to see all types of lumpias.
My favorite Filipino buffet in LV. Very affordable ($10) for all you can eat buffet. Shouts to my kababayans at Nanay Gloria's.

Strictly comparing the food at other Filipino restaurants I give this place a 2.5. No "blood" stew included in the buffet while the other Glorias locations do. Overall food quality/authenticity is OK at best.

We took my mom and mother in law with us to Las Vegas.  They really don't eat other kinds of foods...so we took them to Nanay Gloria's.  They loved it!!  The buffet items were cooked just like they would make at home.  The salmon belly soup was a home run.  EVERYTHING was DELICIOUS...plus when we told them we were from BAKO, they treated especially well!!!

I dined at here four times and enjoyed it each time. Food tastes like my mom's cooking and there's a variety of ethnic food to choose from. Price is reasonable except that the price doesn't include beverages. Unlike Chinese buffet, this one doesn't have a good deserts except for a few fresh cut fruits.

My mother-in-law were in the neighborhood one day & decided to eat some Filipino food before doing some grocery shopping. I have eaten @ their other location. I believe it's the Spring Mountain location (somewhere close to Chinatown) but that place was super small. It's the first time I've eaten @ this location. Waaay bigger! The food wasn't too bad. It was just okay. Edible @ least. It all depends on how you like filipino food cooked. lol. ; ) I'm a filipina so there are some dishes that i'm real picky about as far as taste goes. Lots of dishes to choose from @ least. For AYCE, It was about $7 or $8 for adults and depending on the age of the child they had a price too. I had my 3-yr old daughter w/ me & for her it was $1.99. Weird... But I guess! o_O desserts or pastries were not included w/ AYCE. You pay it separately. They also serve AYCE fresh fruits too. The place is clean & @ least the people who clean up makes their way down around tables often to take away done dishes to give you more room @ your table. Drinks are served in regular soda cans/bottles or water bottles & you pay per bottle. Will come here again if Filipino food is being craved. =)

8.99 buffet.  Kids under3 are free. Cant beat that price for Filipino buffet.   There was no customers though which was surprising.  We just got into town and wanted to try Vegas Filipino food. They had kare kare, dinuguan, maha blanca, sinigang na salmon and more.

I ordered lechon for my sons bday and some fixin's and everything was amazing. They even thru in serving spoons and all purpose sauce.
 Their lunch buffet is one of the freshest and well maintained ones I've been to. They are always switching out the older dishes or almost empty dishes for fresh ones. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
Mediocre at best. Nothing to brag about. Very simple dishes which you can get a better flavor from other places.

Aww....we ended up at the wrong Nanay Gloria's. I thought they'd be the same, but my boyfriend is convinced the other location is better and homeier.  They had a ton of choices, except no lechon or lumpia :( We got there at 4pm and there were still quite a few people there, so they're continually refilling the buffet.
Awesome Filipino food! Authentic home style cooked food! The food is serve fresh. Lechon Kawali is crunchy good! You will surely leave satisfied! Kudos to Nanay Gloria's for food served well!
Tried all the food and they are really very good... Masarap at lutong bahay talaga! Now my favorite go to place when in Las Vegas!

I really enjoyed this place. Only $10 for a buffet! Cheapest buffet in Vegas haha. They have a variety of selections and they're all really authentic Filipino food. I'm not sure what the soup was called but I really liked the sourness of it. The fish and pancit was also one of my favorites! Definitely would come back when I'm in town again.

Nice to have a place to eat when visiting Las Vegas. Foods are great. Will come back again. Good selection of food. You can get a taste of all the food on display since it is a buffet eat all you can. Will definitely come back again.

One of numerous Filipino joints here in Vegas. They recently did some renovations and restaurant area is CLEAN. Not very impressed with the food though. They have your typical Filipino dishes. Tasty but fatty and greasy (very Filipino).

Now the caveat. Food trays lined with clear PLASTIC wrap? I mean come on! Hot food poured over clear plastic wrap IS A HEALTH HAZARD. I don't care if the plastic is "food-grade", but if this is a cost-cutting strategy then too bad, I'd go somewhere else.

Everything here is close to my mama's cooking. Maybe that's why they put the word "Nanay" in the name of the restaurant.  Nanay means mother btw.

Best value in Las Vegas for Filipino food. Forget Goldilocks, forget DJ Bibingkahan, and forget Pinoy Pinay. Nanay Gloria's is the place to be! $7.99 for AYCE Filipino food. Be careful tho, eating too much here will catch you in a food coma quick! I always get the salmon sinigang. TOO BOMB!!! 

For dessert, try the warm ginitaan. It's the white soupy looking dish.

Thank you for being better than the Goldilocks across the street. I went into Nanay Gloria's after a terrible experience at Goldilocks and Nanay Gloria's did not disappoint! Love it here. Good Filipino food and great service!

I called beforehand to see if they had a weekend buffet, then clarified if it was a breakfast buffet; worker on the phone said "yes, everyday."

then we arrive...NO. EGGS... how do you have a filipino breakfast buffet without eggs? how are you supposed to eat longsilog (longanisa, sinangag/fried rice, itlog/egg) without itlog? "longsi" is not a dish!  my mother asked why there were no eggs, and a cook said they're "bawal" (loosely translated as forbidden in tagalog). there were eggs in the fried rice; doesn't seem too bawal to me!

*takes deep breaths*

the food here is okay, nothing special. large selection but some dishes are not cooked to par. the meat in the kare-kare was tough, the lechon bulaklak was undercooked, and the dinardaraan/dinuguan tasted unfresh. furthermore, the few breakfast items they had were not refilled at 10AM, and the staff said that they were done with those dishes.  my brother pointed out that no one in the restaurant was smiling, and my mother said "they're just eating cuz they already paid."

again, the food is, for the most part, fine; just don't expect eggs and don't expect to smile.  on a nice note, my mother complained about the lack of eggs and they gave us free bbq. thx.

Delicious Filipino buffet. Super clean establishment. Courteous service. I ordered take out. Very affordable and tasty. They give you big portions and everything is fresh. I ordered sisig, picadillo, beef stew, menudo, pork adobo along fresh crispy lumpia! AMAZING!! If you are looking for some good Filipino food, this is the place. We shall return.

My family and friends went here after a  long stroll in the strip....coz we have been eating Nanay glorias in LA. and its good there we just couldnt pass this on...and honestly we are not dissapointed..Personally food was just right according my taste buds :D....we will definetely come back here and eat some more of the goodies...it just could have more desserts and more fruits :)..other than that we loved it. and recommend it for ayone who craves for pinoy food.

I heard about this place from family and my husband like this place every time when they visit Vegas they come here. This is my first time eating here, all you can eat for $8.99 atmosphere not friendly, the place is not that nice and no labels on the foods. The only thing I like was the soup with fish. This place is not for me.

I travelled and dined around the country ..and even around the world ... And i havent encountered a restaurant that charged you $1 if u charged your credit card more than $10 and $.50 when you charged your card less than $10 , and maybe charge you $2 if you charge your card $20... And sooo on and so forth , Its a stupid business practice for the costumers . For the person who did charged me at the counter, FYI , i use credit card because i can and i have good credit , and i dnt care what kind of costumers you have who uses cash to pay, i dnt wana assumed that they cant apply for a credit card but you are forcing them to pay cash with your stupid business practice. If your doing this to get away with  your Income Tax Returns...... Karma will come in folds!!! Amen!

This is probably the best filipino food in town. The authentic taste and the experience is simply makes you at home.
Price is super great and very affordable...
Close to the strip...

Staff was nice but as for the food, not so much. Fried rice is really dry, the dessert is an assortment of fruits, and by the time I wanted to get dessert, everything was gone and was not replenished. The free water was not refilled, but the ice bucket was over flowing. 
You have to pay before eating which I found kind of strange for a sit down restaurant.

-buffet
-the guy behind the counter was sooo filipino "corny"
-they did not have much dessert selections but fruit, come on now we are KNOWN for dessert
-the bathroom was big and clean
-a lot of drink choices
-they did not have any ice cream scoops either
-the little grocery store to the side was somewhat dark and possibly closed
-ate the beef steak and onions (i love me some onions) that was swimming in grease
-we are known for grease
-food was tastey but had better
-no sinigang, boooooooo
=RICE FRIED WITH SHRIMP PASTE IS WORTH THE HYPERTESION

For $7.99 per person. I really didn't expect much. I spent $10 for a slice of mediocre pizza at the strip. (I was THAT hungry)

3:00 pm bf decides that he's hungry. Friends were dining at buffet and forgot to invite us lol. Most buffets on the strip close 2:00pm for lunch.

So we caved in. It was a pleasant surprise. The place was simple but clean, nothing too fancy. There was a TV playing the Filipino channel. Bathroom was clean (thank goodness)

Sinigang was yummy. Wasn't shy of sampalok (tamarind)
Rice was cooked well (not too dry or soggy)
Pancit was well seasoned with salt and black pepper and had slices of veggies and pork here and there
Pinakbet was spot on 
Bulalo lacked a bit of flavor but still good enough, you can count the bone marrow in the tray most of it were veggies and broth.
Chicharon was a bit chewy but nothing too bad

for dessert they had a fruit tray, I settled for the watermelon. And it was fresh and sweet. def refreshing for the hot weather last weekend

Again for 7.99 you get your money's worth. Better than the $10 pizza slice I paid for.

The usual "turo-turo" Filipino restaurant. It was empty when we went there, on a Saturday mid-afternoon. We ordered a lot, because we were starving! We ordered dinuguan, munggo, kare-kare, sisig, lechon paksiw. I'd say the food was ok, not great. The rice was dry. Very friendly staff, though. Place is kind of ghetto.

I visit this place earlier as Im craving for filipino dish...It is an affordable place I paid $ 22.44 for 2 persons and they charge $1 extra because I used my debit card. I didn't argue with the extra charge but still its not usual.. 

The place was not at its best not too clean.
The food was ok nothing special the taste was so.. So...the dessert uhmmm dont like it! I've been to couple of buffets here and I can say that this place is ok but not recommendable.
The family just had the buffet lunch. The foods were tasty and very palatable. Better than the first Filipino buffet we went to before. I highly recommend this place.

First time at an all you can eat Filipino buffet and it was absolutely delicious!  

Pros:  hot and tasty authentic Filipino food,  clean and spacious restaurant, opens early at 930am, low price of only $9.99 for adults and as low as $4.99 for kids

Cons:  parking can get tight if it's busy and the location is a bit out of the way,  go early if you can

Definitely recommend!  Can't wait to go back!

Last time I went there the food is very bad.  Fried chicken was head and dry, sinigang na isda has lots of Bones the fish is not fresh, most of the food are cold the shrimp or meat that they put in the dish is very frugal never will I go back there again.  Sorry!
Very very satisfied with the food. customer service was great and food is tasty. Told all my friends and fam about the chicken adobo and lumpia and will be back for more!!

I'm updating this location to give one more star due to its recent renovation/expansion.   Their area is more open and the place definitely looks much nicer and cleaner than before.  Nanay Gloria's still offers an all-you-can-eat option but they also do 2 or 3 entree combo plates which COULD be more value to you.  AYCE costs $9.99 now but they also wanted to charge my four year old $5 and my one year old $2.  They don't even eat a quarter of a plate of food combined.  

We opted to order ala carte, two of their two-entree combos for $7 each.  We received a ton of rice and some noodles and we had four different filipino dishes which all were very reminiscent to our home cooking.   That means very delicious.  We had almost as much food as we would have ate with the ayce option but saved more money.

Our choices for entrees were:  
1) Sisig - Chopped up fried pork, onions, bell peppers.  
2) Menudo - Pork stew with carrots and potatoes.
3) Beef Caldereta - beef & veggie stew (carrots, bell peppers, in tomato-base sauce)
4) Sinigang - Pork belly in a clear sour soup broth.

Drinks are extra and I'd recommend getting a can of soda or bottled water.  The free water they offer from their water dispenser is fine but their bucket of ice is left out in the open and not dispensed through any ice machine.  Can't say I can trust it that much.   With that said, I'd come back here for the food whenever I'm on this side of town.   

Yelp 100 Challenge 2016 - 34/100

Salty for my taste. Didn't find much I liked on the buffet. But I'm Chinese and this read my first time having Filipino food. All my Filipino friend loves it

The place is a small take out looking spot with groceries also  not very nice but ok. I think it's great for Filipinos who want fast casual home style food

Never ate at a buffet Filipino food restaurant before so I thought I'd give it a try. They had just about every Filipino dish I ever ate and then some I would never eat.  Adobo with pork and chicken, dinaguan, sinigang, caldereta, pinakbet, fried fish, tocino, fried rice, steamed rice, menudo and others I don't know the name of.   All good tasting but boy is our cuisine salty!  Pepsi and Coke sodas sold by the can. Not much of a dessert bar; majablanca, orange slices, canned peach slices, and cantaloupe slices. A/C on...nope...so as to make you feel like you're back on the islands I presume. Overall a good place for Filipinos to het their share of Filipino comfort food for $10.99.

Coming from the bay area this place pretty much rocks in terms of value and overall variety... We came here 10am on a Friday and food was of course piping hot. Sisig seems to be the best dish and the hot ginataan mais was a nice treat.

Affordable and good Filipino food with very friendly staff. I went there today for some dinner at 6pm and the food that i got tastes so good and it doesnt taste like it's a left over from yesterday. Ive been to a lot of Filipino restaurants but only this place satisfied me with excellent taste of Filipino food.
went at dinner time . as a buffet, they serve quality food. my top picks are salmon belly sinigang, menudo, and mahablangka.
My coworker's wife recommended this restaurant. I tried almost everything on the buffet and it was all delicious. I can't wait to take some of my friends to try the buffet again.

All I can say is you get what you pay for and for around $7 I got a lot. All the times I've been to Vegas, I've never ventured off the strip but thanks to some kababayans, they recommended this place after a couple of days of overpriced food options elsewhere. 

They had a lot of different options, but I chose the ones I was more familiar with like pancit, fried chicken, kare kare (my fav, but my mom's is still the best!), sinigang, and lots and LOTS of sisig. I know it wasn't the most healthy choice, but this is Vegas and I would pay the $7 just to eat a plate of sisig. 

I took my Vietnamese friend here and even he had more than 3 plates of food. Along with the halo-halo, I would say my $7 was well spent. I will definitely be coming back next time I'm in the city. 

If you're looking for a five star restaurant, go spend $30-$75 somewhere else.

No, no, no. If you want to take delicious cuisine and ruin it, stop here. Whenever fast food is in the title that is always a warning to lower expectations. Sadly there is no bar low enough save one embedded in the center of the Earth.

Food was great!  

It reminded me of what i missed most in the Philippines ;-)

If you skipped breakfast? You can try their sinangag rice, longganiza, tocino and danggit.

I liked the bihon, lechon kawali, monggo and menudo.

My husband loved the dinuguan, while i kept coming back for the pork adobo and grilled pork.

They also have kare-kare, sinigang, chicharon bulaklak, upo, pinakbet and beef with onions.

For dessert, they have maja blanca and fresh fruits.

From the sound of it, we had too much to eat!

Be sure to call the restaurant for directions.  If you use the google map, it might lead you to a different restaurant.  Parking is accessible.

Im not sure if they still charge extra $1 if you use a credit card to pay the bill.  Bring cash. 

They also sell concert tickets of our Kababayan Artistas ;-)

If we go back to Las Vegas, we will definitely be having our brunch at Nanay Gloria's.

Our favorite filipino-food buffet. We always come here when we visit Vegas. They recently underwent a renovation and expanded. It looks way cleaner and I love the openness of the restaurant. It was great before, but felt a bit hole-in-the-wall-ish. Now, there is no wall separating the food from the tables and the food is calling you like heyyyy, look at me. 

Any buffet below $10 makes me feel guilty and Nanay Gloria does just that. Where else can you go and eat all your favorite filipino comfort foods at an affordable price? Plus the food is delicious, replenished often, and kept very clean. I feel guilty eating here, like maybe I shouldn't eat so much but they have soooo much food and many options to choose from.

Dinuguan, kare-kare, calderetta, adobo, fried chicken, lechon kawali, tocino, fried fish, lumpia, pinakbet, pancit, mechado, bistek "beef steak", chicken tinola, and they have either the typical recipe or other variances for example the many "tamarind soup" dishes like pork sinigang, fish sinigang, sinampalukang manok which are all "sort of the same but different" lol. They have the sauces to accompany everything, vinegar, bagoong, mang tomas lechon sauce, banana ketchup, etc. 

Drinks and other specialties items cost extra but they have some sweet items included in the buffet if you need some "dessert" for example, fruit, ginataan mais, maja blanca.

For the people complaining the prices have jumped $2 or that there are no labels for the food, pleeease get over it. I love this place and will come here forever. The end.

I came here with my family in the late afternoon on a Sunday. Although the food appeared to be sitting for a couple hours, it was still hot & delicious. I actually prefer to let my food sit for hours (especially in the fridge), so that the flavors can intertwine even more. If you prefer fresh food, I'd say come when they open or around lunchtime.

Anyways, they have a HUGE selection of all the best Filipino dishes & some that I have never tried before. You seriously can't beat this all-you-can-eat buffet for ONLY $7.99. Sure the place looks a little run down, but it was CLEAN & SANITARY. The bus boy is quick to take away your used dishes, and the lady behind the counter makes sure you're satisfied while you're there.

I've eaten Filipino food all my life, and I can cook some dishes. So I can say that their dishes are QUALITY & bursting with FLAVOR. You know how some buffets that are also cheap prepare their foods in a cheap, watered-down manner? Well, this place doesn't. Their dishes are authentic & quality, and you really get WAY MORE than you pay for.

Oh & btw, their sago gulaman is BOMB, & it's ONLY $1.50!! YUM!

I highly recommend this place. They even have a huge flat screen with TFC playing, so you can watch TV as you eat. Great place to bring your family or even to eat alone!

P.S. I believe they have a $2.99 breakfast special, which I haven't tried yet, but damn, that's a sweet deal.
Great Filipino food,all you can eat Adobo...Chicken,Beef,Pork got ur Pancit behon,Pancit palabok,and soups

Standard Filipino fare, no complaints. I went here with my mom for the lunch buffet since I had to work at nearby Sunrise Hospital shortly after. 

Prices are competitive and food tasty. Interior is basic, service minimal (self-serve). 

Solid establishment, nothing particularly noteworthy either good or bad.

We tried out this Filipino buffet today and it was ok but wasn't that great. No banana q as other posted. They have a fruit stand that only has watermelon on it. The rice was flaky and somewhat hard, seem not fresh anymore. Hubby said he cooks better, lolz. It's $9.99 for a buffet not including any drinks. Kusina ni Lorraine and DJ bibingkahan seem better in our opinion.

We went to Vegas to play WSOP and we were craving Filipino food. We foid this on Yelp and tried it out. This place is legit. You get you food buffet style and then just eat. They have so many selection and the workers are very nice. I would have given them 5 stars but they cut the longanisa wrong.

I'm married to a Filipina who is also a certified French Chef, so maybe I am expecting too much. But the food was just ok, and the atmosphere was kind of cold. Maybe if you are a Filipino that is ok, but I was hoping for a warmer atmosphere, because that is one thing that set Filipinos apart...always warm and welcoming.
This is my favorite filipino cuisine in vegas. Very nice crews and affordable prices.
Authentic Filipino food.  Came with family visiting from out of town.  Delicious and fresh.  We were so stuffed.  Great selection and price.  Will definitely be back for more.

We have dine here several times when we are in town. The food is good,  authentic and affordable Plus Nanay Gloria is very friendly. Unfortunately, rest of the staff are just okay. Lately it has been missing some of our favorites classic dishes (Kare Kare, Lechon Kawali, Adobo Squid, Longoniza and Dinuguaan).  I am hoping that they revisit their menu selection and bring some of the classic traditional favs back.  Also, they should include Lumpias. Gonna have basic traditional food like Lumpias, Pansit and Adobo in any Filipino eatery.
We have become fast "sukis" of Nanay's the first time we came through Vegas! My son loves their adobo with plenty of rich sauce and the dinuguan was delicious!

Coming from the SF Bay Area, I am very familiar with Filipino food and restaurants.  I am very impressed with Nanay Gloria's buffet, which only cost $9.99.  Today, I had salmon sinigang (no bones), ampalaya, dinuguan, pansit etc.  I even had ginataang mais for my dessert.  Everything is clean.  Filipino channel was playing on TV.  The decor is spacious, pleasant and clean.  The food is great.  They even have chicharong bulaklak, which is pretty rare where I come from.  I'm also staying at a Las Vegas strip restaurant where lunch buffet cost $20.  Unfortunately, the hotel buffet was not tasty at all.  I much prefer making this trip to north Las Vegas just to have this tasty buffet!

If you're going here and pay $9.99 for a Filipino buffet.  You need to be really hungry.  They have a lot of selection.  I don't like the idea putting hot food on top of a plastic Saran Wrap. The guy behind the counter was helpful because we had a big group.  Their ginataan mais was really good.  This place is off the strip so you need to drive here or take public transportation.

My first time really experiencing Filipino food other than lumpia.. And I guess I was expecting more because I love ethnic food. There was a big selection of dishes, but no labels so I had to ask a hundred questions to find out what I was looking at. And when I tried the meat and fish, it was either all bones or all fat. Is that how it is supposed to be? The place did not have a warm welcoming environment and it was weird that I had to go fish my silverware out of plastic containers!

It was okay. I stopped by for dinner with my husband and the food looked dry and old. Looked like it was sitting there for a long time. So we turned around and left. Maybe it was just the time of day?

Love nanay gloria's food awesome pansit.
.great customer service too. Love stopping there to grab some food to go

Do NOT eat here!!!!! got empanadas and they were SPOILED, SLIMY, GROSS!!! I was so upset, drove back and got my refund!!!! I know they re-use left overs. I will never EVER go back!!! You've been WARNED!!!!

I was going to hit up the Rio World Carnival Buffet but decided to venture out a bit. Ok, so I spent way too much money in Vegas already so my purse strings started to tighten up a bit. You can't beat $6.99...well you can at $5.99, but I couldn't find a place for that price so here I went. Nanay Gloria's is a total hole-in-the-wall kind of joint. When you're eating you feel like you were at a relatives house. 

The food was good. Extremely greasy, but good. I've always considered Filipino food to be the Mexican food of Asia. Greasy and always makes you want to take a nap afterward. There were many dishes I've never had before, but luckily I had a couple of my good friends who are Filipino help me out in describing to me what I was eating. 

With each crispy-fatty bite I felt my taste buds heightened to a new level. The food was actually good! The lechon had crack sprinkled on top which is the reason I couldn't stop eating it. I tried not to fill up on too much rice so I could try everything else. There were 2 different types of curries. I'm sorry I don't know the proper names, but one was pork and the other beef. Both well seasoned and tasty.

The healthiest thing I consumed while during my Filipino cuisine were probably the 2 cans of Coke. $1 for each can I may add. So my buffet meal came out to under $10. Not bad right? Would I come here again? Sure I would, but first I'd have to have an angioplasty to clean out my arteries from the first time I came.

Nanay Gloria should really consider expanding this place just because it was a little too crowded at times with all the people coming in for take-out orders as well. I said so many "excuse me's" that the phrase lost all meaning!

My husband and I were in Vegas in November 2011 to celebrate our 1st wedding anniversary and were searching for Asian food. When I found this place, I thought, perfect, there's a Filipino place nearby.

I was disappointed. Service was very nice, but very slow. I was 3rd in line and only ordered empanadas but had to wait in line to pay for half an hour - seriously - my husband made sure I knew how long it took. Granted it was not completely their fault since the people in front of me were ordering for their families and seemed to keep changing their orders, but then there should be a re-evaluation of their ordering system. Just have a separate express line for people picking up small ready made items like drinks, chips, etc. instead of the one cafeteria-style line. After eating my empanadas, sadly it was not worth the wait.

Was excited to find a AYCE Filipino in LV. Let down.  Arrived at 5:45 pm concerned place is closing at at 7 pm and may not have enough time to eat.  Well, we were done eating in 20 min.  Food was not tempered right....thus the kare kare was gelatinous along with another curry dish.  Fried salmon ..mouthful of cold grease. Sisig..cold and nothing like biting into cold pieces of pork fat.  Caldereta.  Meat was tough and sauce greasy. All food was luke warm except for the soup which was very hot.  Soon figured out after the first spoonful, was mainly oil from the soup.  My family is partly Philipino so I know the food in the culture is greasy, but this is excessive.  The best thing in this place is the staff who were friendly and the bathrooms that were clean!  Even for the cheap price for AYCE of $10, I wouldn't recommend this place.

Authentic homemade Filipino food. I came here to pick up a couple of party trays to go and everyone loved it. We had lumpias (mini egg rolls), pancit (noodles), and chicken adobo ( marinated chicken stew ) with rice.Prices are very reasonable especially for the quality of food you are getting. The store is very clean and everyone is hard at work. There's a pretty decent size seating area where quite a few people were eating. You can order your food to go or stay and eat buffet style. There's traditional Filipino desert/sweets that changes daily by the check out so it's easy to try something new as you are paying. The lady that works there ( I think is owner and cook ) is so sweet and helpful. She was more then happy to answer my questions of some of foods I was not familiar with. She reminds me of a caring Auntee who wants to make sure your fed. Love it. Parking is a little tight, but not too bad.  Definitely will be back to try other Filipino dishes here.

-First Filipino buffet i have encountered
-Should offer more deserts
-The only thing i ate was the sinigang and the sisig, and it was delish
- The other things on the menu, not so great.
-Not bad for a filipino buffet.

For my morning breakfast i wanted.nothing fancy. I wanted my version of comfort food filipino style.  Housekeeping from Trump international recommended.this place. I walked in and was astounded. For 9.97 a person you get all you can eat filipino food...bistek, munggo, rice, pancit, longanisa, giniling, adobo, mechado, pinakbet, sinigang, ampalaya, chop suey. I was in filipino heaven
 All quality favorites that my lola used to make. Its not fancy, but this made me the happiest on my trip because i felt like i was at home. Best.birthday breakfast. The.employees are sweet and friendly.

Awesome find in Vegas if you're craving Filipino food! $10 for AYCE authentic fresh flavorful Filipino food, that's pretty dang good. Many selections to choose from. If you have a favorite dish, it'll be there. Ate too much of the beefsteak, just too good. Come hungry and you'll definitely leave satisfied. Complimentary drip coffee as well! The place is kept clean and you get to watch TFC while eating haha. The fruit and dessert bar could've definitely been better, had like three selections. Would come back!

i came here with high expectation seeing that my cousins, that have only been in the states for about 4 years, told me about how much more better it is than Pinoy Pinay and all the other chains.

This place gets 3.5 stars! I mean really. A Filipino buffet for $6.99. You cannot beat that with a bat. With an array of selections, it was hard to just pick here and there. My only gripes of this place is the food is a little oily and the rice was a little mushy. Maybe they just put too much oil and water...hahah. Pretty much from there, you get what you pay for. I had everything from the pancit to the beef steak. Pretty tasty food, not too bland, but then again it is what it is. Don't come here expecting you are gonna get GREAT home cooking. You will get what your $6.99 pays for. Have I made my point clear yet? 

Would I come back? Maybe if I was really hung over and I can't find a PHO place that looks decent around the STRIP.

If your craving for some flip food this is the place to go. It's also cheap 7.99 per person on the buffet. It's the closest you can get to home cook food. 

Space is pretty decent because they have an extension so you do not need to worry about not sitting at all. 

Parking is pretty ample so you would have to worry about your car getting scratch.

Spent a week in Las Vegas and was really craving Filipino food. Thought I'd give Nanay Gloria's a try. Was it the best Filipino food I've ever had, no, but did it satisfy my craving? Absolutely! One thing to make note of, it's very confusing when you first walk in as signs say pay first, yet we saw other patrons ordering food then paying. The employees didn't look very happy and weren't very helpful, but that could be the Las Vegas heat. The menu indicates you could either do two and three entree option or just buffet. My group and I ended up being charged for the buffet option even though we didn't want that, but like I mentioned before, it was very confusing. Fortunately, it was only a $2 difference between three entree and buffet. I ended up getting the bistec and beef kaldereta. Wish I skipped the bistec as it was really tough, but the kaldereta was so tender and delicious. I should have loaded my plate up on that instead. My family had the pork adobo, kare kare, fried chicken, and pork bbq. The only complaints I heard was the kare kare didn't have any oxtail and was overly peanut buttery and then my tough bistec. 

So big question, when I'm in town, would I eat here again? Probably not, but only because there are other places with similar set up that I'd like to try before I would decide to visit again. 

Note: There are no labels on the food so if you aren't familiar with Filipino food, you won't know what items are unless you ask. Hopefully, the employees will be more friendly.
Their phone kept ringing and ringing and no one's answering their phone! Its been two days now! In order to value your customers, you have to pay attention to your callers too!
Our family was so glad that we found this place. We were craving for Filipino foods. Price is reasonable.

For Filipino buffet, this place gave us a great first impression.  But after a few more visits, we noticed that the quality of some of their dishes were just average.

One star goes to a pretty good selection of authentic dishes for only $7.  There's about 25 dishes that include Pancit, Chicken Tinola, Lechon Kawali, Laing, Kare Kare, and Crispy Bangus.  The standouts were their Sinagang na Salmon, Adobo with skinless chicken/pork, and their colorful and spicy sisig with bell peppers and crispy pork skin.  
But don't expect to see a large dessert selection in this buffet.  Only Ginitaan and some fruit were available during our visits.

I'll give them another star for having Mang Tomas (A popular Filipino all-purpose sauce used for lechon and other roasts) and Jufran banana sauce available at EVERY TABLE.  Speaking of tables, this place is cleaner than most other Filipino buffet joints I've been to.  

Their unlimited Fried Chicken SKIN (another standout buffet dish) deserves one star by itself.  Where else would you find hoards of crispy chicken skin?  Sadly, or not, I can eat this crunchy goodness like popcorn.  It's not good for you, but hell....whatever happens in Vegas.....right?

If you're Filipino and find relish in the mere thought of your lola or nanay's home cooking, this is the place for you. 

If you're not Filipino, but you're dating someone who is, this can also be the place for you. Or if your friends are the Filipino ones, or if you just like chicken adobo, honestly, a good place for you all. 

It's an all-you-can-eat self-serve buffet style. My favorite dishes were the chicken adobo, pork sinigang, and the deeeelicious warm rice pudding type of dish. So filling, flavorful, and hearty!!!

Been going to this place for many years now. Filipino buffet for less than $13. All you can eat. I actually just flew to Vegas to get some food to go and get my fix. My favorites are dinuguan, monggo, igado, liempo and bikol express. Thank you for maintaining consistency, you guys never disappoint.

This place is cheaper than the "Ito'y sariling atin" store. That is a big plus for me. There aren't a lot of people and the place isn't really decorated but hell, the place is cheap. That's all I care about.  We had to-go because we were ready to go back to our hotel. The woman that put our food together I think was rather tired that day so she made a mistake by putting the wrong kind of soup in our to-go box.  Oh well. I'm not really picky. The food was average and cheap. That's really all I care about.

Horrible service!!!! Never coming back here again. Came for a family party for a baby's christening. Did not provide any utensils and such for the catering. Hospitality is important and they gave none.

Went here with a friend to pick up food for a party we were having on 9/16/12. He's Filipino, so he picked the place out. We picked up a ton of food (you have to order a day ahead and with cash.)

The seafood platter is legit whole fish, not boned, anything. It ended up in the trash because nobody tried any of it and it was REALLY pungent. Come to think of it, it's what the restaurant smells like. I question how fresh the fish was to begin with.

The beef steak in oil is my favorite. Delicious. Also, the Tibok-Tibok (coconut pudding) was delicious. The pancit and mini lumpia were also good. 

Most of the food that was ordered was good, but I wouldn't order the fish.

The positives: I think the food is authentic--for example, there are no labels, which makes me figure that most people who come here know what the items are, and since they know what they are, they probably are actually something that Filipinos eat. The fact that they also sell balut also points toward authenticity. Sadly, I am not a Filipino food expert. Also, the service is very friendly, and an older woman working behind the line explained several things. Some of the dishes--particularly a somewhat sweet one with either baby squid or baby octopus--were tasty. It's also quite affordable.

The negatives: the place isn't as clean as I'd like it to be. They had a section for water but the containers were all empty, which is particularly problematic for a Vegas summer day. Some of the dishes were less than remarkable. Particularly, a dish with carrots had such large slices of carrots that they were a bit undercooked and difficult to eat.

Overall: This is in the category of 'restaurants I would like to like more than I did.' I think they have a niche for low-cost Filipino food. But it's not a place that I'd race back to go to.
